newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Southeast spot power climbs on heat, outages.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Southeast spot power climbs on heat, outages.

text.p: Spot electricity prices in the U.S. Southeast climbed Monday on hot weather and continued outages of several large generation plants in the region, said industry sources.
After the passage of Hurricane Fran last week, the region was left with hot and muggy weather since this weekend.
Some regional power providers, whose transmission assets were ravaged by Hurricane Fran, scrambled to cover the native electric load in the wholesale market, traders said.
Those with extra power to sell today commanded high premiums for their incremental generation, they said.
Tennessee Valley Authority, the largest energy provider in the Southeast, reportedly purchased spot power today on an hourly basis in the $28.00-$30.00

Within the Southeastern Electric Reliability Council (SERC), peak, non-firm power for Tuesday was bid at $25.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), compared with a range of $22.50-$23.50 for Monday delivery on Friday.
At the Georgia/Florida border, peak, non-firm power prices for Tuesday were valued in the $28.00 area, compared with Friday's $23.50.
In the Florida pennisula, non-firm, peak electricity prices for Tuesday delivery were quoted in the $31.00-$33.00 range, up from Friday's prices in the $28.00 area for Monday delivery.
Florida Power & Light Co's 839 megawatt (MW) St Lucie 1 nuclear power plant will likely operate at reduced power for the next two weeks, while it repairs one of the unit's main transformer.
Florida Power Corp's 825 MW Crystal River 3 nuclear unit remained shut because of lube oil leak.
Carolina Power & Light Co's 683 MW Robinson 2 nuclear unit was taken off line Saturday to begin a 40-day refueling outage.
